name: Joan
comment info:
What appears at the top of the article is not a graph. 
    
    It is a map: a choropleth map, to be specific: a powerful tool that allows those reading it to discern regional patterns, or the lack of them, in the variable being mapped. 
    
    We see them every election night, when we watch as states flip from some neutral tone to red or blue, showing a Reblican or a Democratic victory in that state  Did you ever once hear the even most ill-informed of election night pundits refer to those maps as graphs?
    
    Any data collected on a state-by-state basis can be mapped the same way: ditto data collected county by county, district by district, country by country, etc. Commonly a range of dark to light tones of a single color distinguishes places with higher to lower unemployment rates, or numbers of millionaires per 100,000 residents, or mean family income. The number of different datasets that can be mapped this way is essentially limitlesss. 
    
    The ease of grasping data mapped this way is striking. Now think of the same data on a bar graph. No meaningful relationships can pop out that way. When New Jersey and New York share similar data values on a map, it's not as conspicuous as when New York and New Mexico do. The question, "Why?" arises, followed by several others. That's a launching pad for critical thinking. We need all the critical thinking we can get.
    
    Next lesson: Greenland is WAY smaller than Africa, despite what some maps seem to show. Please alert Mr. Trump.
